issue.title: Inference: run inference without yaml

repository.name: geo-deep-learning
repository.description: Deep learning applied to georeferenced datasets

issue.body:
If #154 is covered, then we can easily adapt inference.py to run without a yaml. We could think of 2 mandatory arguments:
1. image url (local path or from web)
2. model url (local path or from web to checkpoint.pth.tar)

There could also be a third, optional argument:
- number of gpus. 

If this third argument is optional though, we'd have to determine what the default behavior is:
- if multiple gpus are available, run on one gpu only?
- if multiple gpus are available, run on all available gpus? This implies that #182 would be solved.

issue.title: add git hash and yaml parameters to hdf5 and checkpoint.pth.tar

repository.name: geo-deep-learning
repository.description: Deep learning applied to georeferenced datasets

body: With the PR switch to hydra we head le the saving of all the parameters, but not in the pth, do we still want that?

> With the PR switch to hydra we head le the saving of all the parameters, but not in the pth, do we still want that?

I feel this will be useful if we want to input a checkpoint from command line at inference. The architecture in the checkpoint could overwrite the default model architecture. There may be an easy way to do this with hydra, but I haven't found it.

@CharlesAuthier it seems parameters are still saved in the .pth: https://github.com/NRCan/geo-deep-learning/blob/develop/train_segmentation.py#L781

What did you mean by 

> we handle the saving of all the parameters, but not in the pth, [...]

?
The Idea of removing it fall into water, but in all the hyperparameters are saved in another location too, so if we wanted to get rid of it's possible.
For the inference pipeline, it's best to keep parameters inside the checkpoint to help override default params at inference. Needs developments related to #246
